And some metals like Zinc

The universe was about to enter
a super creative phase where it produces
all the elements heavier than iron

To make the missing pieces in our birth of
the universe jigsaw would take some of the most
powerful explosions the universe has ever seen

2039.text:
Our Universe has already celebrated
its 500 millionth birthday.

2044.text:
There are still another 13 billion more to go

Giant new stars have made many of the elements
in the world we see around us.

2059.text:
heavy metals like chromium and zinc,
and expensive ones like gold and platinum

To finish the job, the universe conjures up
the most amazing phenomena since the Big Bang

When the giant stars that made the lighter elements

creating incredible amounts of energy

These explosions were so powerful

Tony Mezzacappa from Oak Ridge

Life as we know it certainly would not exist

2118.text:
They are very clearly one of
the key links in our chain of origin
from the Big Bang to the present day

2126.text:
One of the most recent and biggest

seen in the southern hemisphere in 1987

2134.text:
When a supernova like 1987A explodes
it emits light containing the signatures
of the elements within it

2143.text:
By examining this spectrum of light
scientists can calculate what elements
are being forged inside the exploding star

2153.text:
Massive stars evolve to an onion-like
configuration at the end of their lives.

2159.text:
They have an iron core and outside of the iron
core are layers of successively lighter elements

2167.text:
Inside the iron core, the temperature
rises to 8 billion degrees, nearly 300
times hotter than the center of the sun

2176.text:
It is so hot the iron atoms that
have sunk to the stars core are torn apart.
The core destabilises

2184.text:
The cores then collapse on themselves
in a fraction of a second, the collapse
proceeds to very, very high densities

2194.text:
The core collapses at speeds of
more than 43,000 miles per second.

2199.text:
A volume the size of the earth crunches down
nearly 6 times the size of Manhattan in an instant

2209.text:
If one were to take one cubic centimetre of
that matter, that would be the size of a sugar cube

2216.text:
that sugar cube would be so dense that
it would weigh as much as the entire human race

2223.text:
The core rebounds, like a compressed rubber ball
- and launches a massive shock wave.

2229.text:
The shock wave hurtles out,
smashing through the different skins of the star

2237.text:
As it punches through the outer layers
of the star, the energy generated
restarts the element production line

2244.text:
Atoms are smashed together to make brand new
heavier elements - all heavier than iron

2252.text:
Then the star explodes and the shock wave
pushes the shrapnel like debris outwards
- further and further into space

2261.text:
In a very real sense our lives depend on
the stars in the Universe, without their lives
and deaths, we would not be here today

2274.text:
These astonishing images taken
by the Hubble Space Telescope show
the aftermath of these giant explosions

2281.text:
Nebulae - giant clouds of debris

Swirling inside are big new atoms
- gold, silver, zinc and lead

Without supernovas, our world would be

So I'm sure that, that Paris Hilton doesn't

But really, if it weren't for exploding stars,

Nine billion years after the Big Bang and all

The universe has grown up into a vast,
complex place made up of billions
of galaxies and uncountable stars.

In a quiet corner of the Milky Way,

It's full of the rich debris left over

and when it reaches a critical mass

What's left over forms a disc of

The clumps of dust and gas
become bigger and bigger.

Planets form¡­

Over the next 500 million years

canopy of gas - the atmosphere.

The first life appears.
Just single cells at first

but as the aeons pass those tiny single

We tend to disassociate ourselves

of course is completely wrong,

and so when we talk about the origin

we're actually talking about the origin

Everything we can see on our planet was

Scientists like Krauss believe

These atoms have been around
since the dawn of time,

2436.text:
and when I was young my mother used to tell me,
don't touch that, you don't know where it's been,

2440.text: and she would have been amazed.

After almost 14 billion years the universe
has really only just gotten started

2455.text:
Now we take a journey into the future
to see how it all ends.

2462.text:
The universe we live in
is nearly 14 billion years old

2467.text:
It has created the raw materials
for everything we see around us.

2470.text:
The stars, the planets, trees, cities
- automobiles - even us.

2477.text:
Our world is complete.
But the universe is still evolving.

Scientists have come up with many theories

2487.text: We know our universe began in a Big Bang.

What we don't know yet is what the future
of our universe is going to be

2493.text:
Our universe may end with a bang or whimper,

2498.text:
One theory suggests that our universe

2503.text:
every star, galaxy and planet,
every atom will start to collapse

ending in a single super dense pinpoint
- known as the 'big crunch'

2517.text:
To find out if the Universe really
is going to crash back in on itself

scientists first need to discover if
it's still expanding or if it's slowing down

Astrophysicist Saul Perlmutter studies the death

If you have enough of
these exploding stars, these supernovae,
that you've measured their brightness,

2546.text:
so the ones that look fainter and fainter and fainter

And so you have some supernovae that
little bit brighter, they're more nearby,
some that are a little bit fainter

2554.text:
so they're a little bit further, and some that

Type 1A Supernovas are similar to the supernovas

2564.text:
They differ in one important fashion -
they always explode with the same exact brightness

2572.text: This is because they are created in the same way

2577.text:
Two stars circle each other held together
by their gravitational attraction

One is shrivelled and super dense glowing

2589.text:
The other star has bloated
to an enormous size

2592.text:
it's a red giant that is burning
the last of its fuel

2596.text:
As the two stars orbit each other,
the White Dwarf sucks gas from its companion

2605.text:
When it is precisely 1.44 times
the mass of our sun,

2609.text:
the White Dwarf crumples, collapses then
explodes releasing a blinding burst of energy

2616.text:
Every Type 1A supernova explodes
at the same 'tipping point'

and so are equally bright and visible
across the vast distances of the universe

2628.text:
Perlmutter needs to find hundreds of

how fast they are moving away from us

2636.text:
By comparing the positions and
dates of all these supernovas

Perlmutter can calculate

2650.text:
The expansion of the universe

When we began the project of course

Now when we actually started looking

Perlmutter's astounding discovery means

the earth, planets, people, atoms,

Atoms will fall apart.
